name: Celebrating
description: In good times and bad, there is always a reason to celebrate.  Find out here the different ways in which Bristol people have let their hair down.

audio.name: M Shed ICT, audio interview, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Maherush talks to Raj and Sodesh about arriving in Bristol
audio.description: Maherush talks to Raj and Sodesh about their lives in Bristol after they moved from the Punjab and Kenya in the 1960s and 1970s. They discuss their favourite Indian music, films and dance, and how their children's upbringings differed from their own.

name: Raj and Sodesh talk about arriving in Bristol

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, My Family's Journey by Rukhsar
video.description: Easton resident Rukhsar Mussagi was born in India. Her story tells how she and her parents came to Bristol.

audio.name: M Shed ICT, audio interview, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, SS Chadha talks about moving to Bristol in 1969
audio.description: SS Chadha talks to Hari about moving to Bristol in 1969 and keeping his heritage alive by playing the tabla and cooking Indian food at the Chelsea Road gurdwara.

name: SS Chadha talks about moving to Bristol

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, The Lodger by Hari Newnham
video.description: Hari Newnham of Cotham, Bristol, presents 'The Lodger', his story of how his parents met. He describes how his father, a white British man, arrived in Bristol and fell in love with his Indian mother.

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Meri Yaadein (My Memories) by Soni
video.description: Soni Kaur, of South Asian origin, grew up in Barton Hill. In her story, she shares her memories of her Bristol homeland.

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, My Grandad by Maherush
video.description: Maherush Khan shares her memories of her grandfather and imagines how his life in India compared to her experience of growing up in Bristol.

audio.name: M Shed ICT, audio interview, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Zehra sings in three different languages
audio.description: Zehra Haq, founder and Chief Executive of Dhek Bhal day centre in Barton Hill, sings two nursery rhymes in three languages (Punjabi, Malay and English) that have passed down from her mother to her grandchildren. A Singaporean of Punjabi descent, she sings in the different languages in order to pass on her cultural heritage to successive generations.

audio.name: M Shed ICT, audio interview, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Older women at the Dhek Bhal day centre discuss home-cooked food
audio.description: Novelist Nikesh Shukla and Soni Kaur speak to women from the Older Women's Group at the Dhek Bhal day centre in Barton Hill about their memories and stories of home-cooked food; they discuss their favourite recipes and cooking methods, hoping to pass these on to the next generation to ensure that their heritage continues and thrives.

name: Women at Bristol's Dhek Bhal on home cooking
The Cookbook of Us, Volume 1
description:
Nikesh writes:

My mother once told me, "If you want people to know who you are, offer to cook for them". A meal is heritage and taste, history and smell all wrapped up together into the alchemy of a plate of food. You can learn a lot about a person from

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, A History of the Bristol Asian Youth Club
video.description: This short film, made by members of the Bristol Asian Youth Club, presents a concise history of the Asian Youth Club at The Mill and explores what it means to the different generations who use it.

name: History of the Bristol Asian Youth Club

audio.name: M Shed ICT, audio interview, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Durga talks about her musical career
audio.description: Durga talks to her son Hari about her musical career as a vocalist and player of the veena in the South Indian Carnatic tradition, and her impressions of Bristol after living in India and Libya.

audio.name: M Shed ICT, audio interview, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Patel talks to Soni about emigrating from India
audio.description: Patel talks to Soni about how he moved from India to Uganda and ultimately to Bristol, UK, in search of a better life. He describes how he struggled to find a job as a doctor.

name: Patel talks about emigrating from India

audio.name: M Shed ICT, audio interview, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Jagdish discusses his life as the driver at the Asian Day Centre in Easton
audio.description: Interviewed by Hari Ramakrishnan, Jagdish discusses his life as the bus driver for the Asian Day Centre in Easton and his love of old Punjabi music. The Asian Day Centre is part of the Easton Community Centre.

name: Jagdish on his job as a bus driver in Bristol

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Bristol's Vaisakhi Festival, 2014
video.description: AJ's story follows the Vaisakhi parade held in Bristol on 18 May 2014. The Vaisakhi festival celebrates the birth of Sikhism and includes a procession in which members of the Sikh community visit each of the local gurdwaras (places of worship). Bristol has four gurdwaras: two in St George, one in Easton and one in Eastville.

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, The Ganesh Chaturthi festival in Bristol
video.description:
Mahesh Patel tells the story of Ganesh Chaturthi, the Hindu festival in honour of the god Ganesh, as celebrated in Bristol at the end of August 2014. The action begins inThe Bristol Hindu Temple at Redfield (Bristol's only Hindu temple) and ends in the Bristol Channel, just off Portishead.

Ganesh is the elephant-headed god in the Hindu pantheon, the remover of obstacles and the giver of wisdom.

The film was shot by Rakhi Solanki and produced in partnership with The Asian Arts Agency and Biggerhouse Film for the Desh Project.

description:

description: The Great Western Cotton Factory in Barton Hill opened amid much fanfare in 1839. It was the biggest cotton mill outside the Lancashire textile district. Bristol had high hopes at the time of major trade in cotton with America but it never materialised.

description:
Massive Attack was formed in 1988 from the remaining members of hip hop crew The Wild Bunch. The band comprised Robert Del Naja (Delge), Grant Marshall (Daddy G) and Andrew Vowles (Mushroom).

video.description: Durga Ramakrishnan talks about growing up in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu; she discusses her life as a musician and how her family moved between India, Africa and Bristol in the UK.

name: Durga's Story
description: Durga Ramakrishnan talks about her experience of growing up in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu; she discusses her life as a musician and how her family moved between India, Africa and Bristol in the UK.

name: Headline News
description:
Bristol has a far longer history of newspaper publishing than most cities. Here are just a few milestones.

1702: Bristol printer William Bonny starts the Bristol Post Boy. A 1704 edition at the Bristol reference library is the oldest example of a British

name: Read All About It!
description:
Bristol's newspaper industry grew thanks to rising literacy and improving technology. Technology will hopefully help it survive in future, too.

Bristol's earliest papers were just a single sheet with news from London and Europe. They were popular with lo

name: People in the News
description:
Bristol's newspaper history features many larger-than-life characters, from hot-heads and hustlers to people whose honesty got them into trouble.

Some of the first editors were printers, publishing newspapers to supplement their income. Felix Farley, the

name: Hold the Front Page!
description:
Whenever anything important took place in Bristol, the city's reporters and photographers were usually among the first on the scene. 

Journalism is often said to be "the first draft of history", and this applies just as much to local news as major world

name: Sarah Siddons
description:
Actress Sarah Siddons is said still to appear at the Bristol Theatre Royal, over 200 years after her last performance there. Her ghost is reputed to haunt the wings of the stage.

Whether or not this is true, Siddons made a tremendous impact on Bristol th

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Philosophical Meaning by Mahesh
video.description: Following a visit to M Shed, Easton resident Mahesh Patel discusses his passion for poetry, visual arts and antiquities. "As a creative person," he says, "I'm 95% poet and 5% artist... my aim is to fuse poetry and art together".

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, Akbar and Birbal visit Swindon
video.description: This film, produced by the Bristol-based Asian Arts Agency, takes an intimate look at a theatrical workshop, focussing on the Tales of Birbal, as developed by Mashi Theatre. The session enabled children and their families to take part in storytelling and puppet making. The Birbal stories (often known as the Akbar-Birbal stories) are a prominent and popular part of Indian folk lore and are still recounted by South Asian families living in Bristol.

name: The Bristol School of Artists
description:
For we joke and we pun and we bask in the sun, all brethren of the brush.'
Rev John Eagles

The Bristol School of artists was a circle of artists who worked together in the city between 1810-1840.  Edward Bird, the Wolverhampton-born artist had settled in

name: The Braikenridge Collection: Now and Then
description: Bristol is one of the best recorded cities prior to the invention of photography, largely because of George Weare Braikenridge, the collector and antiquary. Braikenridge collected widely, from stained glass and metalwork to illuminated manuscripts and ivo

name: Nicholas Pocock: Mariner Artist
description: Nicholas Pocock (1740/1-1821) was one of the leading marine artists of his time, from the 1790s to the 1820s. In his paintings he recorded battles at sea that took place during the Seven Years War (1756-63), the War of American Independence (1775-82) and

video.name: M Shed ICT, digital video, Desh project, Asian Arts Agency, The Unknown Museum by Maherush
video.description: Taking M Shed as an example, Maherush Khan thinks about how history is represented in a museum, what is shown to the public and what might be missing.

name: Spicer's Hall
description: Spicer's Hall on Welsh Back, by Bristol Bridge, was the home of a medieval merchant.  Richard Spicer was MP for Bristol in 1355 and three times Mayor, and he bequeathed his home to the Mayor and Corporation of Bristol in 1377.  A later occupant was Robert

name: The Merchant Venturers of Bristol
description: Bristol's wealth has long been based on trade. Merchants were powerful people, and were involved in the running of the city from about 1200.  Members of the medieval 'Guild Merchant' were usually members of the Corporation as well, and so politically powe

name: Silver penny of King Cnut
description:
This tiny silver coin tells us a great deal about the importance of Bristol.  It was made at a mint in Bristol between 1017 and 1023 during the reign of King Cnut - the king famous for supposedly trying to stop the tide coming in.  

The fact that Bristol

name: Bristol Cattle Market
description:
From the Middle Ages until 2005, there was a cattle market in Bristol.  Farmers from Wales and Ireland as well as from the local area brought their cattle, sheep and pigs to the market to sell to local butchers. 

Elizabeth I granted the City the right to

audio.name: M Shed ICT:  People  Gallery, kiosk 2 Trading Locally BUTCHERS Shop - The Christmas Market

name: The local butcher's shop
description: Before the refrigerator became a basic household item, most people bought fresh food every day from their local butcher, baker, grocer and greengrocer. In 1885, there were 26 butchers shops in the fast-growing industrial suburbs of Bedminster and Redcliff

audio.name: M Shed ICT:  People  Gallery, kiosk 2 Trading Locally GROCERS Shop Air Raid over Bristol

name: The grocer's shop
description: Meat and other foods were rationed during World War 2.  Everyone had a ration card, and had to register with a local butcher and grocer where they would buy food according to their weekly ration allowance - the amounts differed for men, women and children

name: Pedlars
description:
English, Scottish and Jewish pedlars were a common sight in the 1800s.  They carried their goods in a box, and walked from town to town.  Pedlars  often sold cheap but attractive or useful goods, such as hardware, haberdashery, silver and jewellery.

The

name: Craft Guilds
description: Trained craftsmen (rarely women) joined guilds, which set the standards and prices for their work.  There were over 20 craft guilds in Bristol in the 1400s. These included the cordwainers (shoemakers), weavers, dyers, bakers and coopers (barrel makers).

name: Markets and market trading
description: From the medieval market stalls in the High Street to the farmers' markets of today, Bristolians have enjoyed the bustle and haggling of the marketplace.  Wholesale or retail, buyers could get what they needed from the general or specialist markets.  Spec

name: Trading with Ireland
description: One thousand years ago, when slavery was an accepted part of Anglo-Saxon life, Bristol's merchants were selling enslaved white people to Viking settlers in Ireland. A shortage of labour in Ireland meant that there was a ready market for workers.  Some of

name: Trading northwards
description: The River Severn gave Bristol's merchants an important route to the midlands and the north.  From the 1500s to the coming of the canals and railways, the River Severn as far as Shrewsbury and the River Wye as far as Hereford were Bristol's main inland tra

name: Trading with Wales
description: Bristol was the regional trade centre from about 1200, and merchants as well as merchandise came to the city.  Wales was an early and close trading partner.  Bristol merchants took many apprentices from Wales, and by about 1400 many of the city's merchant

name: 'Ave a banana!

video.description: Monika describes herself as a Bristol-born Indian and the daughter of successful shop owners in Cotham. In her film, she talks about  her parents' shop and other aspects of her life in Bristol, including her uncle's career as a Bristol bus driver and her enduring love of Bhangra music.

name: Cod and a new world
description:
Politics were as important as economics to the merchants of Bristol.  When the English lost their French lands in 1453, Bristol merchants had to find look further afield for trade and find new markets.  

Robert Sturmy led an expedition to the eastern Med

description:
John Pinney inherited a rundown sugar plantation on Nevis in 1762.  Careful management of the plantation, his sugar importing business in Bristol and his investments made him a rich man: he left £267,000, worth about £15 million today.

description:
Edward Colston's name is synonomous with Bristol and the slave trade, despite the fact that he was based in London for all his working life.  What did he do to become the revered philanthropist / reviled slave trader of the city of his birth?

Edward was

name: Who is Jack in the Green?

description:
Attendants accompany Jack on his journey, clashing sticks in time to hypnotic music played on drums, melodeons, whistles and fiddles, and often singing. At intervals the procession pauses for a lively dance around Jack before dancing onwards.

Jack's atte

With slight variations from year to year, Jack travels from M S

Starting as a small one day event in 1974, the Ashton Court Festival grew into probably Britain's largest free festival.  

Run by volunteers, it retained a community feel and attracted fans of all ages with its mix of music, performance, and local crafts

Sir George White, 1854-1916
Led Bristol to become one of the world's leading centres for aerospace engineering Businessman who founded the
British and Colonial Aeroplane Company in 1910, which continues as BAe.

He also developed Britain's first electric

description:

Founder (with others) of the disciplines of quantum mechanics and quantum electrodynamics.

Bristol-born theoretical physicist who received the Nobel Prize for Physics (with Erwin Shrodinger) for 'the discovery of new productive forms

description:
Dr Sukhsaga Datta, 1890-1967
Contributed to India's independence struggle.

Doctor who was active in the anti-colonial movement. He seconded the resolution at the Labour Party conference in 1945 calling for the withdrawal of Britain from India. He was act

Thomas Howard, 1817-1896
Improved the harbour.

Docks engineer who designed the entrance lock to Bristol's City Docks, still in use today.

William Budd, 1811-1880
Saved lives by showing that cholera bacteria were carried in drinking water.

Doctor whose work on cholera led to improvements in Bristol's water supply to protect against water-borne disease.

Beryl Corner, 1910-2007
Set up the special care baby unit at Southmead Hospital, Bristol.

First paediatrician in the south west of England, she improved the care of new-born babies through her work.

John McAdam, 1756-1836
Improved Bristol roads.

Surveyor to the Bristol Turnpike Trust, he developed a construction method which used a camber so that rain water drained off the road to prevent damage. This became known as 'Macadamisation'.

description:
Elizabeth Blackwell, 1821-1910
The world's first female doctor.

Bristol-born medic who fought to qualify as a doctor. She graduated from Geneva Medical College, New York in 1849. She was the first woman to be enrolled on the British Medical Register, and

description:
Sarah Guppy, 1770-1852
Patented ideas for engineering and gadgets.

Inventor who patented many ideas including a method of making safe piling for bridges. This was first used in suspension bridges ten years ahead of Brunel's Clifton suspension bridge.

description:
Dr Amber Young, born 1963.

Engineer at Rolls Royce and BAe who led the development of the Olympus aircraft engine for Concorde and created the Pegasus engine for the Hawker Siddeley Harrier.

description:
Reverend Dawnecia Palmer, born 1958
Reduced violent street crime in Bristol.

Evangelical pastor who founded the Peacemaker Prayer Patrols in 2002, to use prayer and communication as a way of reducing knife and gun crime in areas of the city.

Volunteer who has supported Henbury & Brentry Scout group since 1976 and developed a holiday play scheme in the area.

Carole Brookes,born 1952,

Headteacher of St Barnabus CEVC Primary School in St Pauls 1985-1995, who raised standards of achievement and improved the learning environment at the school.

description:
Banksy 

Graffiti artist, political activist and film director

Banksy is the internationally known artist whose identity is unknown. His stencilling technique features on walls and bridges throughout the world, including various locations around Bristol.

Russ Conway, 1925-2000
Popular pianist and composer who influenced the work of Elton John.

John Latimer, 1824-1904
Recorded Bristol's history for the future.

Journalist who wrote a history of Bristol from 1601 to 1900 from old documents and chronicles.

Bristol City striker who stayed loyal to his club.

Footballer who made 645 appearances and became the club's all- time top scorer with 351 goals, refusing lucrative offers to move to other clubs.

She tells the story of her immigration - how her parents moved from the Punjab to Kenya and how she herself moved to Bristol in the early1970s with her husband and young family.

During the Second World War, the Government cut all unnecessary imports into Britain.  The import of bananas stopped in 1941.  It began again after the war on 30th December 1945, when the first cargo arrived at Avonmouth aboard the Tilapa.

The SS Wells City was the second ship of that name in the Bristol City Line fleet.  She was launched in 1890, and sold to a Greek shipping company in 1928. 

The blue star logo of the company was painted on the funnel and flown as the house flag.

video.name: BRO BROFA/0049
video.description:
Digital copy of original film, entitled 'Kino - Girl of Colour', filmed in 1920 by by William Friese-Greene in Biocolour.This was a two-colour additive process, in which colour-sensitive black and white film was shot and projected through alternating red-orange and blue-green filters. While this gave an illusion of true colour, it tended to suffer from flickering and red and green fringing. This digital reproduction is not an accurate representation of the original, as it accentuates the red and green.

The film shows a girl sitting at a table eating and moving fruit about. It ends with a man sitting at a table opening a cigarette case and a girl sat in a chair sorting through an assortment of flags. The man may be Friese-Greene himself.
